title: After Woodford scandal, more savers put their faith in tracker funds
text:
Neil Woodford’s fall from grace has plunged rival fund managers into crisis.

Many fear that the collapse of his investment empire — valued at £15 billion at its peak — could be a hammer blow to the public’s confidence in star stock pickers.

Their reputation has been gradually eroded since the 2007-08 financial crisis, with investors placing their faith in so-called tracker funds instead.

Also known as passive funds, trackers aim to replicate the performance of a specific index, such as the FTSE All-Share Index.

Robot fund managers: Also known as passive funds, trackers aim to replicate the performance of a specific index, such as the FTSE All-Share Index

Their share of the investment market has risen by 13 per cent in the last year alone, according to the Investment Association.

By comparison, active funds try to outperform the market and are run by managers — such as Woodford — who buy and sell stocks based on their own research.

Only 39 per cent of active funds have beaten the market over the past five years, according to investment platform AJ Bell.

Investors pulled £3.5 billion from active funds in the UK in the three months to September — a quarterly record — according to fund settlement service Calastone.

Earlier this week another UK leading fund manager, Mark Denning of Capital Group, was forced to resign following accusations that he had bought shares for his own benefit in the same companies his funds had invested in.

Now experts are warning that the demise of the sector’s biggest names could scare off novice investors.

Adrian Lowcock, from Willis Owen, says: ‘What happened with Woodford wouldn’t easily happen in a passive fund. Most trackers follow listed indices and therefore you can always sell the underlying investments.

Weak link: Active funds try to outperform the market and are run by managers - such as Neil Woodford

‘Also the investors in the fund are more likely to know what they have bought, so there is unlikely to be large sell-offs in a tracker.

‘It’s a shame that it will put people off investing, but going passive is better than not investing at all.’

Tracker funds attract new investors because they grow modest but stable returns over the long term without requiring you to have in-depth investment knowledge. They also tend to have lower fees as they do not require an active manager.

Justin Modray, from Candid Money, recommends the Vanguard FTSE UK All-Share Index, which would have returned £14,067 if you had invested £10,000 five years ago, with an annual fee of 0.08 per cent.

James Norton, from Vanguard, says investors have started to question whether fund managers’ fees are value for money.

He says: ‘There are skilled active managers out there, but high costs often kills their return. I have a management fee of 1 per cent and I need a return of above that to do as well as the market does.’

Mr Modray says a worthy active fund is Franklin UK Equity Income, which has provided a five-year return of £15,207 on a £10,000 investment, with an annual fee of 0.52 per cent.

Analysts insist there is still space for skilled fund managers acting with conviction.

Trackers are all well and good when the market is growing, but quick-thinking managers can come into their own during a downturn.
